content:
Hey @T-libs, @T-libs-api, and everyone else who likes to regularly join our meetings (cc @The 8472 @Ashley Mannix @simulacrum):

Can y'all fill in this time picker, to see if we can find better meeting times? https://www.when2meet.com/?13259902-sOmVH

(Ignore the specific dates, it's about your availability on those weekdays in general.)
i filled it out, but as usual, please rank me as the lowest priority. even if y'all did have a meeting at one of my available times, it's likely i'd only be able to make ~half of them anyway.
done -- though I can't say I'd call myself a regular attendee :)
@simulacrum well you attended 100% of the last 1 meetings ;)
filled my times out
when2meet seems pretty nice too
way better than doodle
:+1:, I like the when2meet interface better, though I wish it had an "if need be" option like Doodle does.
Yea, that's true
so looks like the conclusion from the poll so far is: timezones suck.

starting to wonder if we can think of a different way to synch up, other than weekly meetings. for most of the things we discuss in the meetings, i'm not sure if a video call is the best way to do them. but without the meetings, a lot of things end up standing still.
I've seen meetings done by Zulip, and they never seem anywhere close to as productive.
i don't think i'm going to be able to keep having weekly meetings this late. but it also seems like any other time doesn't work for most people. not sure what we should do.
we could try rotating meetings
try to pick two sets of meeting times that together cover everyone and maximizes overlap
Those are so painful for people trying to attend all of them. :(
FWIW, I don't know about others, but I answered the previous time poll just with my "yes" times and not with my "if need be" times.
I'd be happy to try another round and dig deeper into what's possible rather than what's preferred, especially if we have options for both.
I can probably also dig out some more extreme time availabilities if needed
though similiarly to mara, I expect I won't enjoy those meeting times for very long

@Ashley Mannix also wants to join the meetings again. but that means we have people -9 from me and +9 from me. almost perfectly distributed across the 24 hours around the globe. there isn't going to be any time that isn't late at night or very early in the morning for someone
it doesn't seem like I saved the password I used for this one though so I cannot update the times I already gave :S

Mara said:

Ashley Mannix also wants to join the meetings again. but that means we have people -9 from me and +9 from me. almost perfectly distributed across the 24 hours around the globe. there isn't going to be any time that isn't late at night or very early in the morning for someone

I don't know about others, but I can manage either somewhat-early-morning or very-late-night without feeling like it isn't sustainable, so I'm happy to compromise more on time. (day of the week is the item I'd prefer to keep contained.)
How many folks in the meeting are in US/Pacific?

Libs meetings have always been very, very early for me and it is hard to wake up enough to actually participate. Having a split time might not be ideal for folks who want to attend everything, but having a single time that isn’t compatible is also not ideal for folks who want to attend that one. I guess the tricky part of a split time would be either just covering the same thing twice and not actually making decisions in case the other crew will, or having a topic you really want to participate in be in the wrong timezone.

It doesn’t seem like there are any easy answers, does it.
It's even harder when a topic comes up (or goes unexpectedly deep/detailed) that wasn't expected, and that you would have wanted to participate in.
we need a flat earth, with just one time zone

like, the downstream benefits of making it so that we can coordinate effectively across timezones seem to massively outweigh any potential downsides of letting these conversations be split across different subgroups of the libs teams
but we already have a lot of async focused work flows so I don't really expect our meetings to be substantially different

My feeling is that focusing on getting everyone involved and resolving issues around split attendance is likely the best path forward. For example, I can imagine resolving the issue about people missing conversations by making it so that whenever we make a decision in one of the meetings the attendees write up a summary of the discussion, the decision, and what justified it. Those who couldn't attend can then quickly get up to speed and leave additional comments that they would have said, but this also has the benefit of making sure all of our decisions are well documented which will benefit other ecosystem participants following along.
assuming we can actually set things up so we can still coordinate effectively
Another possibility would be making sure that we don't make irreversible decisions in meetings, only via async mechanisms like FCPs.
We can always start an FCP or poll or similar in a meeting.
That sounds good but I think the flat earth idea might also have some legs
@Ashley Mannix 20 of them if Discworld is to be believed. ;)
And four trunks.
/me adds to our action items: "make earth flat"
@rfcbot concern how do we keep the fish from swimming into space
